Expectation1: Provide guidance and wisdom based on life experience
Situation1: A grandchild directly asks their grandmother for help and advice with a serious concern in their life.
Expectation2: Arrive at the polling station during designated voting hours
Situation2: Late-afternoon errands leave just a couple of hours before the polls close.
Story: I was just about to grab my coat and head out the door when my phone buzzed. It was my granddaughter, her voice trembling as she asked if she could come over right away. She needed to talk—something serious, she said, and I could hear the weight in her words. My heart ached; I’ve always promised to be there for her, to listen and offer the wisdom I’ve gathered over the years. But as I glanced at the clock, I realized the polling station would close in just a couple of hours. I’d already put off voting until the last minute, thinking I’d have plenty of time after my errands. Now, I was torn. My granddaughter needed me, but so did my community—my vote mattered, and I’d always believed in fulfilling my civic duty. The pressure built inside me, two parts of myself pulling in opposite directions, each demanding my presence, each expecting me to do the right thing. I stood in the hallway, keys in hand, heart pounding, uncertain which path to take.
